child_demographics: Two children: E.G. (8 years, female), R.G. (5 years, female)
legal_issues_identified: Relocation Application (s.46 FLA); Parenting Time & Responsibilities (s.40–41 FLA); Child Support (s.147–149 FLA)
summary_holding: Relocation permitted due to enhanced stability, caregiver support, and respondent's conduct posing risk to children; parental responsibilities shared with final decision-making to applicant.
winning_argument_type: Relocation justified by caregiver stability, financial/emotional benefits under Barendregt, and respondent's criminal conduct impacting child safety (s.37(2)(j) FLA).
failed_argument_type: Failed to rebut relocation justification; reliance on outdated maximum contact principle rejected by Barendregt; minimized criminal recognizance's impact on child well-being.
judicial_disdain: B.G. has demonstrated poor parental judgement. This puts his children’s safety, security, and well-being at risk (¶92). The allegations significantly affected the children (¶109).
scc_precedent_applied: Y - Barendregt v. Grebliunas (relocation framework); Y - Gordon v. Goertz (best interests analysis); Y - Young v. Young (pragmatic best-interests assessment)
precedent_gap: None noted. Court strictly applied SCC precedents, rejecting maximum contact presumption per Barendregt.
strategic_takeaway: Relocation may be granted where primary caregiver's stability is enhanced, especially with evidence of opposing parent's conduct creating risk (FLA s.37(2)(j)). Maximum contact arguments are invalid post-Barendregt.
counsels_analysis: Issue: Whether relocation served children’s best interests. Rule: FLA s.46 requires assessing applicant’s reasons against s.37 factors. Application: Criminal recognizance (s.810 CC) against respondent directly impacted child safety (s.37(2)(j)), while applicant’s move improved financial/emotional stability (Barendregt ¶169). Respondent’s family violence history (s.37(2)(g)) and disregard for Elders’ directives further undermined his position. Cultural preservation received minimal weight due to parties’ prior choices. Conclusion: Relocation granted as it maximized safety and caregiver capacity under s.37(3).
